items.title: Adelaide Writers' Week director resigns following author's removal
items.description: The director of Adelaide Writers' Week has resigned, after days of furore regarding the decision to cancel a scheduled appearance by a Palestinian-Australian author.

items.title: NASA to roll Artemis II rocket to launchpad Saturday

featured_image.name: NASA plans to roll Artemis II rocket to launch pad on Jan. 17

items.description:
NASA is set to begin final preparations for humanity's return to lunar space this weekend, with the agency planning to roll the massive Space Launch System rocket and Orion spacecraft to Kennedy Space Center's Launch Pad 39B on Saturday, January 17[1][2][3].

The 4-mile journey from the Vehicle Assembly Building will mark a critical milestone for Artemis II, the first crewed mission to the Moon since Apollo 17 in December 1972. If all goes according to plan, four astronauts could be launched toward the Moon as early as February 6[2][4].

items.title: Donald Trump's latest 'spectacular unforced error'
items.description: A criminal probe into the US Federal Reserve chair threatens to undermine the US dollar and the global monetary system. Local analysts warn the implications for Australia are profound.

items.title: Albanese calls national day of mourning for Bondi victims on January 22
items.description: There will be a national day of mourning for the victims of the Bondi terror attack on January 22, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says.

items.title: Kevin Rudd to resign as Australian ambassador to the US a year early
items.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says Mr Rudd will depart the role on March 31, a year before the posting was due to end, and says it was Mr Rudd's call.

items.title: Three people rescued in flood emergency in central Queensland as ex-Cyclone Koji moves west
items.description: A flood emergency warning remains in place for Clermont, as already-saturated western communities are being warned of possible heavy rains from ex-Cyclone Koji.

items.title: Trump to meet Venezuelan opposition leader Machado at White House

featured_image.name: Trump to host Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado ...

items.description:
Venezuela's interim government announced on Monday the release of 116 political prisoners, though human rights organizations have only been able to verify roughly half that number. The releases come after U.S. pressure following the capture of former President Nicolás Maduro by American forces earlier this month.

The discrepancy highlights ongoing tensions between the interim government's claims and the reality on the ground. The Penitentiary Services Ministry stated that those freed had been "deprived of their liberty for acts associated with disrupting the constitutional order and undermining the stability of the nation."[1][2] However, the human rights group Foro Penal reported that only 41 prisoners had been released as of Monday, including 24 freed overnight.[3][4] Another watchdog, Justicia, Encuentro y Perdón, confirmed 53 "duly verifiable" releases and called the current pace "clearly inadequate."[5][6]

items.title: Live: Harrowing return to Harcourt as Victorians tally bushfires damage
items.description: Firefighters continue to battle fires across the state after the grim news that a person had been found dead and at least 400,000 hectares have been burnt. Follow live.

items.title: White House weighs Iran nuclear talks as Trump considers strikes

featured_image.name: MOMENTS AGO: President Trump speaks to reporters on Air Force One in route  to DC

items.description:
The White House is considering Iran's proposal to enter nuclear negotiations even as President Donald Trump leans toward authorizing military strikes against the Islamic Republic, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter[1][2].

Trump announced Sunday that Iran had reached out to the United States the previous day proposing to negotiate a nuclear agreement[2][3]. "Iran reached out because they want to talk," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One[3]. The President indicated his administration was working to arrange a meeting with Tehran but warned he might need to take action beforehand as the death toll from protests continues to rise[3].

The overture arrives amid a brutal crackdown on nationwide demonstrations that erupted December 28 following the Iranian rial's collapse to a record low of 1.4 million to the dollar[4][5][6]. At least 538 people have been killed in the two-week uprising, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency, which has a history of accuracy during previous unrest in Iran[4][7]. More than 10,600 individuals have been arrested[7].

items.title: Blame game begins over faulty Queensland rain gauges
items.description: Graziers say it was "back to the old days" as under-resourced rain gauges failed in north-west Queensland, with the widespread floods killing almost 50,000 cattle.

items.title: How the Iranian regime uses the dead in its propaganda machine
items.description: As images of rows and rows of dead bodies at a morgue in Tehran circulate, the regime is accused of making it impossible for families to grieve.

items.title: Iran says it's ready for war or talks as Trump weighs strike

featured_image.name: Abbas Araghchi, Iran's top diplomat, says Tehran is ready ...

items.description:
Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi declared Monday that Tehran is "fully prepared for war" but remains open to diplomacy with the United States, as President Donald Trump considers military intervention over the Iranian government's deadly crackdown on nationwide protests.

"The Islamic Republic of Iran is not seeking war but is fully prepared for war," Araghchi told a conference of foreign ambassadors in Tehran, broadcast on state television[1][2]. "We are also ready for negotiations, but these negotiations should be fair, with equal rights and based on mutual respect."

The statement came hours after Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday that Iranian leaders had called him seeking to negotiate and that "a meeting is being set up"[3][4]. However, Trump warned the U.S. "may have to act before a meeting" due to the escalating violence against protesters.

items.title: Cuba rejects U.S. talks after Trump threatens oil cutoff

featured_image.name: Trump team puts a target on Cuba, with threats and oil ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump declared on Sunday that Cuba will no longer receive Venezuelan oil or money, demanding the Caribbean nation "make a deal, BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE" in a Truth Social post that drew a fiery rebuke from Cuban leadership. The threat marks an escalation of pressure on Cuba following the U.S. capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on January 3.

Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel responded defiantly on X, stating, "Cuba is a free, independent and sovereign nation. No one tells us what to do."[1][2] He added that Cuba "does not attack; it has been attacked by the U.S. for 66 years, and it does not threaten; it prepares, ready to defend the homeland to the last drop of blood."[3][4]

On Monday, Díaz-Canel stated there are "no conversations with the US government except for technical contacts in the area of migration," while expressing openness to dialogue "founded on principles of sovereign equality, mutual respect, adherence to international law."[5][6]

items.title: Markets shudder as White House goes to war with everyone
items.description: In the past week, the US has dramatically expanded and accelerated its attacks both inside and outside its borders. Here's where Australia stands in the fray.

items.title: Iran imposes near-total internet blackout as protests spread

featured_image.name: Iran in paralysis as internet blackout freezes banks and daily life

items.description:
The most widespread protests in years have swept across Iran over the past two weeks, with hundreds killed as authorities impose a near-total internet blackout and security forces escalate their crackdown on demonstrators demanding an end to clerical rule.

As the digital blackout enters its fifth day, the Human Rights Activists News Agency (HRANA) reported Monday that at least 544 people have been killed, including 496 protesters and 48 security personnel, while more than 10,600 individuals have been detained since demonstrations began on December 28[1][2]. Iran Human Rights, a Norway-based monitoring group, said unverified reports suggest the actual death toll could exceed 2,000, with much of the violence obscured by the communications shutdown[2].

items.title: Greenland seeks NATO defense umbrella as Trump refuses to rule out force

featured_image.name: Denmark's PM says Greenland showdown at 'decisive moment'

items.description:
Greenland's government announced on Monday that it will intensify efforts to ensure the Arctic territory's defense falls under NATO's framework, as US President Donald Trump doubled down on his ambition to acquire the island, refusing to rule out military force.

"All NATO member states, including the United States, have a common interest in the defence of Greenland," Greenland's coalition government said in a statement published on the Naalakkersuisut (government) website[1][2]. The move comes as Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One that "one way or the other, we are going to have Greenland"[3].

items.title: Apple picks Google's Gemini AI to power next-gen Siri

featured_image.name: Apple in talks to use Google's Gemini AI to power revamped Siri ...

items.description:
Apple officially confirmed Monday that it has selected Google's Gemini AI models to power the next-generation version of Siri, marking one of the most consequential partnerships between the two longtime rivals in the competitive artificial intelligence landscape.

"After careful evaluation, we determined that Google's technology provides the most capable foundation for Apple Foundation Models and we're excited about the innovative new experiences it will unlock for our users," Apple said in a statement shared with CNBC[1][2].

The announcement immediately boosted shares of Alphabet, Google's parent company, helping push it past the $4 trillion market capitalization threshold for the first time. Alphabet shares rose as much as 1.7% to $334.04 on Monday, with the company recently overtaking Apple to become the world's second-most valuable corporation behind Nvidia[3].

items.title: UK regulator opens first Online Safety Act probe into X

featured_image.name: UK regulator launches investigation into X over Grok sexualised imagery

items.description:
Britain's communications regulator Ofcom announced Monday that it has opened a formal investigation into Elon Musk's social media platform X over concerns that its AI chatbot Grok is being used to create and distribute sexualized deepfake images of women and children. The probe marks the first significant enforcement action under the UK's Online Safety Act targeting a major social media platform.

"There have been deeply concerning reports of the Grok AI chatbot account on X being used to create and share undressed images of people — which may amount to intimate image abuse or pornography — and sexualised images of children that may amount to child sexual abuse material," Ofcom said in a statement[1][2][3].

items.title: Alphabet becomes fourth company to hit $4 trillion valuation
items.description:
Alphabet broke through the $4 trillion market capitalization threshold on Monday, joining an exclusive club of companies to ever reach the valuation as investors bet heavily on the Google parent's dominance in artificial intelligence.

Shares rose as much as 1.7% to $334.04 on the news that Apple had selected Google's Gemini models to power the next generation of Siri, according to CNBC[1][2]. The announcement cemented Alphabet's position as Wall Street's second-most valuable company, surpassing Apple for the first time since 2019[3][4]. Only Nvidia, Microsoft, and Apple have previously crossed the $4 trillion mark[5][6].

items.title: Situation in Iran 'under total control', claims government
items.description: Iran claims weeks of anti-government protests across the country have subsided, blaming the US and Israel for the violence.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
